meta.title: Make Your Bed: Little Things That Can Change Your Life...And Maybe the World
meta.author: Admiral William H. McRaven

parts.title: Lessons from a 2014 Military Speech
parts.body: Preface: In 2014, I gave a commencement speech at my alma mater, the University of Texas. Initially worried about my military background, I found students embraced my ten lessons from Navy SEAL training, which resonate with life's challenges. People shared how small acts, like "making their bed every morning," inspired resilience. This book expands on those lessons, incorporating stories of individuals exemplifying discipline, perseverance, and courage.

parts.title: The Importance of Small Habits in SEAL Training and Life
parts.body: The barracks at SEAL training is a simple building near the beach in Coronado, California. It has basic rooms with just beds and closets. As the day begins, the trainees are expected to start by making their beds perfectly. Instructors inspect uniforms rigorously, checking for precise alignment and cleanliness. If standards are not met, trainees face physical consequences like being made into a "sugar cookie," which involves getting wet and covered in sand. Making the bed correctly is a small but important task that demonstrates discipline and attention to detail. Throughout his career, the author describes how making his bed became a constant amidst chaos. Even during major events like 9/11 and his recovery from a parachute accident, the act of making his bed symbolized a return to normalcy and a way of claiming control over his day. In Iraq, even when sleeping on Army cots, the ritual of tidying his sleeping area provided a sense of pride and routine. These repeated actions helped him and others handle the hardships of military life, teaching that while life can be unpredictable, maintaining small disciplined habits can provide strength and solace.

parts.title: Parachute Accident and Recovery Lessons
parts.body:
Lesson from a Parachute Jump Accident

In SEAL training, a critical incident taught me the importance of relying on others, paralleling the lesson from the rubber raft teamwork. During a parachute jump, I collided with another chute, resulting in chaos at 5,500 feet. Entangled and partially unconscious, I finally deployed my parachute, landing far from the drop zone with severe injuries. Recovery seemed impossible, threatening my SEAL career due to the intense physical demands and medical evaluations required. Yet, crucial support from my wife, friends, and military leader Admiral Olson championed my return.

Community Support in Recovery

Bedridden, self-pity was counteracted by my wife Georgeann’s tough love and care, physically aiding my wounds and mentally bolstering my spirit. This community of support in various forms – emotional, physical, and professional – highlighted that no individual, even in elite SEAL groups, thrives alone. Just as in basic SEAL training, success in overcoming life’s trials demands a reliance on others around us, underlining that the journey of life requires teamwork and mutual support.

parts.title: Lessons in Determination and Overcoming Unfairness
parts.body: The young midshipman visited the SEAL training facility in Coronado with hopes of becoming a SEAL. He met Lieutenant Doug Huth, who shared insights about SEAL training. The midshipman compared himself to a frail civilian looking at photos, doubting the man could endure SEAL training. However, he learned that this man was Lieutenant Tom Norris, a Medal of Honor recipient considered one of the toughest SEALs. Norris's story exemplified that determination outweighed physical attributes, inspiring others to prove critics wrong. Later, the midshipman experienced a lesson in unfairness during a SEAL training exercise. Tasked with becoming a "sugar cookie" for a training rule violation, he was instructed to get wet and sandy. This challenged his patience, as becoming a "sugar cookie" was the instructor's arbitrary choice—a test of resilience. Seeking approval from Lieutenant Phillip L. Martin, the midshipman learned that SEAL training emphasized overcoming unfair situations, instilling the need to persevere regardless of circumstances.

parts.title: Moki's Resilience and Legacy
parts.body: Although initially, there was hope that Moki might recover, the paralysis from the cycling accident was permanent. Moki displayed remarkable resilience, never showing self-pity or blaming the accident for his lot in life. Instead, he became an accomplished painter and founded the Super Frog Triathlon. Moki's story illustrates how unfairness in life doesn't determine your future. Many great individuals, including Moki, are defined by how they deal with life’s challenges and injustices.

parts.title: From Adversity to Leadership and Daring Greatly
parts.body: July 1983 was a challenging time for me as I faced consequences for trying to change my SEAL squadron. After being relieved of my position, my reputation was damaged among officers and enlisted men. However, I had two choices: quit or persevere and prove my capability. Opting for the latter, I took every opportunity to outperform others during an overseas deployment. This dedication led me to regain respect and eventually, I took command of a SEAL Team and later, many SEALs. By 2003, I was a one-star admiral in combat zones, making numerous decisions that at times resulted in failure. These failures taught me to learn, motivate myself, and face risks as a true leader. Later, the passage transitions into a reflection on daring greatly. While on a SEAL training obstacle course, I learned an essential lesson in overcoming fear by attempting the Commando Style for the Slide for Life. This experience became invaluable in 2004 during a risky daylight rescue mission in Iraq, where taking risks led to success. Throughout my career and life, understanding that “Who Dares Wins” taught me that living in fear of failure or hardship limits one’s potential. Accepting and understanding calculated risks can reveal what is truly possible.

parts.title: Courage Against All Odds
parts.body: Swimming into darkness with sharks and overcoming fear is a powerful experience faced by aspiring SEALs. Ensign Marc Thomas and others navigated the ocean under challenging conditions, knowing threats like the great white shark lurked beneath. Despite the physical challenges and mental obstacles, their strong desire to succeed as SEALs pushed them forward with courage. They understood that without courage, individuals and societies remain vulnerable to bullies and tyrants. Perseverance through hardship, exemplified by American soldiers who ousted Saddam Hussein, serves as a lesson that strength overcomes fear, allowing for victorious resolutions.

parts.title: A Fallen Soldier's Final Moments
parts.body:
A Fallen Soldier's Farewell

At Bagram Air Base, a solemn Ramp Ceremony took place for a fallen warrior. Soldiers lined up, forming an honor guard while a band played "Amazing Grace." The soldier's comrades acted as pallbearers, carrying a flag-draped casket onto a waiting C-17 aircraft. A pastor recited Isaiah 6:8, honoring the sacrifice of the fallen, in a moment filled with profound grief and dignity. In these dark moments, when the C-17 departed to Dover Air Force Base, the country honored the soldier's bravery. Stories from Iraq and Afghanistan illustrated the nation's ability to support and pride itself on the courage of its warriors, reinforced by instances where communities united, honoring the fallen with respect and pride. These moments taught the importance of holding on during life's dark times to find the strength to carry on.

parts.title: Never Quit: Transform the World with Simple Actions
parts.body: The commencement speech at the University of Texas emphasizes that individuals have the power to change the world. The speaker highlights the SEAL training experience and lessons learned there, emphasizing the importance of never quitting. He shares an inspirational story of a courageous Army Ranger, Adam Bates, who faced immense adversity with determination, symbolizing the strength of the human spirit. The speech underscores how taking small actions each day can lead to monumental change, much like making one's bed to start the day on the right note. The speaker insists that if everyone changes the lives of just ten people, those changes will ripple through generations. His message is clear: taking risks, showing resilience, and the determination not to give up are lessons that apply universally. He concludes by stressing that taking small, purposeful actions can lead to transforming one’s life and the world at large. The advice given is relevant to everyone, regardless of their background or situation, reminding the graduates that big change starts with simple steps like making your bed.

parts.title: Resilience and Adversity
parts.body: SEAL training teaches valuable lessons. Despite all efforts, uniform inspections always found "something" wrong, leading to a "sugar-cookie" punishment. Through this, students learned resilience; sometimes life just makes you a sugar cookie, and you must keep moving forward. SEALs faced rigorous physical events daily, and failing to meet standards led to a "Circus," or extra calisthenics. While fatiguing, Circuses built strength and inner resilience, proving failure isn’t the end but a path to growth. If you want to change the world, embrace the lessons taught by adversity and never quit.
